facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 97 and 98 of 1952 from the Judgment and Decree dated the 13th October 1950 of the High Court of Judicature at Patna.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 97 and 98 of 1952. Appeals under Articles 132 1  and 133 1  c  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Decree dated the 13th October 1950 of the High Court of Judicature at Patna in Miscella

facts.text: Appeals under Articles 132(1) and 133(1)(c) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 97 and 98 of 1952. Appeals under Articles 132 1  and 133 1  c  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Decree dated the 13th October 1950 of the High Court of Judicature at Patna in Miscella

facts.text: State of Bihar is the appellant in both appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bihar is the appellant in both the appeals. The first three respondents in Appeal No. 97 are the sons of the fourth respondent therein, viz. Kumar Rani Sayeeda Khatoon  hereinafter referred to as Kumar Rani . The said Kumar Rani is also the first respondent in Appeal No. 98. The other respondents in both the appeals are Government Officers under the appellant, the State of Bihar.

facts.text: First three respondents in Appeal No. 97 are sons of Kumar Rani Sayeeda Khatoon.

anchor.surface_text: The first three respondents in Appeal No. 97 are the sons of the fourth respondent therein, viz. Kumar Rani Sayeeda Khatoon  hereinafter referred to as Kumar Rani . The said Kumar Rani is also the first respondent in Appeal No. 98. The other respondents in both the appeals are Government Officers under the appellant, the State of Bihar.

facts.text: Applications to High Court dated 5th July 1950 and 28th July 1950 under article 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: These are two companynected appeals arising out of a. companymon judgment of the High Court of Patna on two applications to it dated the 5th July, 1950 and 28th July, 1950, under article 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Kumar Rani born in the territory of India.

anchor.surface_text: The applications before the High Court arose with reference to action taken against  1  the property, and  2  the person, of Kumar Rani by the Officers of the Government of Bihar, under the following circumstances. Kumar Rani was admittedly born in the territory of India and claims to be the lawfully wedded wife of Captain Maharaj Kumar Gopal Saran Narayan Singh of Gaya by virtue of an alleged marriage between them in 1920 according to Arya Samaj rites and subsequently according to Muslim rites, She owned and 1261 possessed companysiderable properties.

facts.text: Kumar Rani claims marriage in 1920 to Captain Maharaj Kumar Gopal Saran Narayan Singh according to Arya Samaj rites and subsequently Muslim rites.

anchor.surface_text: Kumar Rani was admittedly born in the territory of India and claims to be the lawfully wedded wife of Captain Maharaj Kumar Gopal Saran Narayan Singh of Gaya by virtue of an alleged marriage between them in 1920 according to Arya Samaj rites and subsequently according to Muslim rites, She owned and 1261 possessed companysiderable properties.

facts.text: Kumar Rani created wakf of 427 villages on 4th May 1946 for maintenance of herself, sons and descendants.

anchor.surface_text: In 1946 she created a wakf of her properties companysisting of 427 villages for the maintenance and support of herself, her sons and their descendants, by executing a deed of Wakf-ulalAulad dated the 4th May, 1946, by which she divested herself of all her interest in the said properties and vested them in Almighty God.

facts.text: Kumar Rani appointed herself sole mutwalli for lifetime or until relinquishment, sons to succeed as joint mutwallis.

anchor.surface_text: She appointed, herself as the sole mutwalli for her life time or until relinquishment, and her three sons to succeed her as joint mutwallis. The deed also provided that the net income was to be spent for the maintenance of herself and her three sons with the direction that number more than half should be spent by the wakifa for her own use.

facts.text: Kumar Rani went to Karachi in July 1948.

anchor.surface_text: In July, 1948, Kumar Rani went to Karachi. In December, 1948, she returned to India from Pakistan on a temporary permit and went back to Pakistan in April, 1949.

facts.text: Kumar Rani returned to India from Pakistan in December 1948 on temporary permit.

anchor.surface_text: In December, 1948, she returned to India from Pakistan on a temporary permit and went back to Pakistan in April, 1949. On the 21st June, 1949, the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949  Bihar Ordinance No. III of 1949  came into force.

facts.text: Kumar Rani went back to Pakistan in April 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In December, 1948, she returned to India from Pakistan on a temporary permit and went back to Pakistan in April, 1949.

facts.text: Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 came into force on 21st June 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st June, 1949, the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949  Bihar Ordinance No. III of 1949  came into force.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian issued notification on 2nd September 1949 declaring wakf properties as evacuee property under section 5.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property issued a numberification on the 2nd September, 1949, under section 5 of this Ordinance, declaring all the properties companyprised in the abovementioned wakf estate to have vested in the Custodian as being evacuee property.

facts.text: Custodian took possession of properties between 20th September and 2nd October 1949.

anchor.surface_text: He took possession thereof between the 20th September and 2nd October, 1949.

facts.text: Kumar Rani came back to India on 14th May 1950 under permanent permit.

anchor.surface_text: On the 14th May, 1950, Kumar Rani again came back to India under a permanent permit obtained from the High Commissioner for India in Pakistan.

facts.text: Permanent permit cancelled on 12th July 1950 by Deputy High Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: This permit was, however, cancelled on the 12th July, 1950, by the Deputy High Cominissioner,on the ground that this was wrongly issued, without the companycurrence of the Government, a.-, required by the rules made under the Influx from Pakistan  Control  Act, 1949.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector of Police, Gaya issued notice directing Kumar Rani to leave India by 31st July 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this cancellation, the Sub-Inspector of Police, Gaya, issued numberice to Kumar Rani directing her that since her permanent permit had been cancelled, she should leave lndia by the 31st July, 1950.

facts.text: High Court allowed both applications.

anchor.surface_text: Both these applications were allowed by the High Court and hence these appeals by the State on leave granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Appeals heard before Supreme Court on 26th and 27th October 1953, Appeal No. 97 remanded for finding.

anchor.surface_text: These two companynected appeals came up for hearing be-fore this Court on the 26th and 27th October, 1953. This Court after hearing companynsel on both sides was of the opinion that one of the essential facts  to be mentioned in detail herein below when dealing with Appeal No. 97  requisite for a proper decision of Appeal No. 97 had been assumed without investigation and that it was necessary to have a finding thereupon after taking evidence.

facts.text: Kumar Rani went to Karachi in July 1948 temporarily for medical treatment - story doubted by High Court and Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: As regards her allegation that when she first went to Karachi in July, 1948, she did so temporarily for the purpose of medical treatment, the learned Judges of the High Court were number inclined to accept her story.

facts.text: In application for temporary permit Dec 1948, Kumar Rani stated domiciled in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: When she came to India in December, 1948, she did so on a temporary permit stating in her application for the said permit that she was domiciled in Pakistan and accordingly representing herself to be a Pakistani national.

facts.text: Letter dated 2nd June 1949 from Kumar Rani to son relinquishing mutwalli office - found not genuine by High Court after remand.

anchor.surface_text: She had written a letter dated the 2nd June, 1949, addressed to her ,second son, Kumar Fateh Singh, whereby she relin- 1266 quished the office of mutwalli in the wakf estate

facts.text: Supreme Court finds Kumar Rani migrated to Pakistan after 1st March 1947.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt on these facts that she must be held to have migrated from the territory of India after the 1st March, 1947.

facts.text: Permit cancelled validly as issued without concurrence of Government.

anchor.surface_text: This is a case, therefore, number of a valid permanent permit having been issued and the permit holder returning to India on the strength thereof and the same having been arbitrarily cancelled. It is a case of an unauthorised issue of an invalid permit which has been properly cancelled.

issues.text: whether, in the circumstances, Kumar Rani was a citizen of India at the date of the order

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises is whether, in the circumstances, Kumar Rani was a citizen of India at the date of the order. The contention of Kumar Rani is that though it is a fact that she did go to Pakistan in the year 1948, she went there only for a temporary purpose,

arguments.claim: Kumar Rani fits evacuee definition under Bihar Ordinance

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first point is concerned an evacuee is defined as follows in the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 A person who, on account of the setting up of the Dominions of India and Pakistan or on account of civil disturbances or the fear of such disturbances, leaves or has, on or after the 1st day of November, 1946, left,

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees with High Court finding after evidence

arguments.claim: Evacuee property definition in Bihar Ordinance includes wakf property and trustee/beneficiary interest

anchor.surface_text: the contention is based on the definition of the phrase evacuee property in the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949, which is as follows Evacuee property means any property in which an evacuee has any right or interest or which is held by him under any deed of trust or other instrument.

arguments.claim: Successive repealing laws confirm vesting and broad definition includes trustee interest

anchor.surface_text: The Central Ordinance which repealed the Bihar Ordinance as well as the Central Act which repealed the Central Ordinance, each contain section 8 (2) providing that where immediately before the commencement of this Ordinance (Act) any evacuee property in a Province has vested in any person exercising the power of Custodian under any law repealed hereby, the evacuee property shall on the commencement of the Ordinance (Act) be deemed to have been vested in the Custodian

holdings.text: Kumar Rani is not a citizen of India as she migrated from the territory of India to Pakistan after the 1st day of March, 1947, and Article 7 overrides Article 5 even for a migrating wife.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt on these facts that she must be held to have migrated from the territory of India after the 1st March, 1947. Even if therefore article 5 can be said to be applicable to her on the assumption that Captain Narayan Singh was her husband and that her domicile was that of her husband, the facts bring her case under article 7. Article 7 clearly overrides article 5.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show migration after 1 March 1947; Art 7 expressly overrides Art 5 with no exception for wives; domicile principle inapplicable.

holdings.text: Proviso to Article 7 does not apply as Kumar Rani returned under an invalid permanent permit which was properly cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 10 of the Permit System Rules, 1949, framed by the Central Government under section 4 of the Influx from Pakistan (Control) Act, 1949, provides that a permit for permanent resettlement in India may be granted by the High Commissioner or Deputy High Commissioner only after securing the agreement of the State or the Province where the applicant intends to settle. Rule 29 provides that every permit issued under the rules shall be liable to cancellation at any time, without any reason being assigned by the issuing authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permit issued without required state government concurrence per Rule 10, hence invalid; cancellation valid per Rule 29.

holdings.text: The order directing Kumar Rani to leave India is valid as she is not a citizen.

anchor.surface_text: Hence the proviso to article 7 can have no possible application. The applicant, is, therefore, not a citizen of India and the order passed by the Sub-Inspector of Police, Gaya, dated the 23rd July, 1950, directing Kumar Rani to leave India was accordingly valid. This appeal must therefore succeed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from non-citizenship under Art 7; no violation of Art 19.

holdings.text: Kumar Rani is an evacuee under the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first point is concerned an evacuee is defined as follows in the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 A person who, on account of the setting up of the Dominions of India and Pakistan or on account of civil disturbances or the fear of such disturbances, leaves or has, on or after the 1st day of November, 1946, left, any place in the Province of Bihar for any place outside the territories now forming part of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Migration facts fit definition post-prescribed date without accepted temporary reason.

holdings.text: Kumar Rani did not relinquish office of mutwalli; letter dated 2nd June 1949 is not genuine.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having taken evidence on the matters at the hearing after remand and having considered the same, has clearly found that the letter was not genuine. We have gone through the finding and the material relevant thereto, and can find no reason not to accept it. There is, therefore, no substance in this second contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding after remand and evidence accepted by Supreme Court.

holdings.text: Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 applies to wakf property and mutwalli's beneficial interest therein as evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: the contention is based on the definition of the phrase evacuee property in the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949, which is as follows Evacuee property means any property in which an evacuee has any right or interest or which is held by him under any deed of trust or other instrument. ... The words used in this definition are of sufficient amplitude and we are of the opinion that the Bihar definition comprised also wakf property and interest therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad definition includes trustee/beneficiary interest; confirmed by repealing Central laws' savings clauses and definitions.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt on these facts that she must be held to have migrated from the territory of India after the 1st March, 1947. Even if therefore article 5 can be said to be applicable to her on the assumption that Captain Narayan Singh was her husband and that her domicile was that of her husband, the facts bring her case under article 7. Article 7 clearly overrides article 5.
In the result both the appeals are allowed. The appellant in the circumstances will get only the companyts incurred before the High Court on remand in Civil Appeal No.
wallis as well as the owners of the beneficial interest in the wakf estate. It being undisputed that these three remained in India throughout, it is c

edges.explanation: The holding that the proviso does not apply due to invalid and properly cancelled permit directly addresses the issue of whether the proviso applies and cancellation is illegal

anchor.surface_text: Rule 10 of the Permit System Rules, 1949, framed by the Central Government under section 4 of the Influx from Pakistan (Control) Act, 1949, provides that a permit for permanent resettlement in India may be granted by the High Commissioner or Deputy High Commissioner only after securing the agreement of the State or the Province where the applicant intends to settle. Rule 29 provides that every permit issued under the rules shall be liable to cancellation at any time, without any reason being assigned by the issuing authority.
In the result both the appeals are allowed. The appellant in the circumstances will get only the companyts incurred before the High Court on remand in Civil Appeal No.

edges.explanation: h3's holding that the order is valid as she is not a citizen supports the rejection of the Article 19 violation allegation in c4

anchor.surface_text: Hence the proviso to article 7 can have no possible application. The applicant, is, therefore, not a citizen of India and the order passed by the Sub-Inspector of Police, Gaya, dated the 23rd July, 1950, directing Kumar Rani to leave India was accordingly valid. This appeal must therefore succeed.
In the result both the appeals are allowed. The appellant in the circumstances will get only the companyts incurred before the High Court on remand in Civil Appeal No.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first point is concerned an evacuee is defined as follows in the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 A person who, on account of the setting up of the Dominions of India and Pakistan or on account of civil disturbances or the fear of such disturbances, leaves or has, on or after the 1st day of November, 1946, left, any place in the Province of Bihar for any place outside the territories now forming part of India.
In the result both the appeals are allowed. The appellant in the circumstances will get only the companyts incurred before the High Court on remand in Civil Appeal No.

edges.explanation: Holding h5 that Kumar Rani remains mutwalli supports h6 applying Ordinance to her beneficial interest as evacuee property

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having taken evidence on the matters at the hearing after remand and having considered the same, has clearly found that the letter was not genuine. We have gone through the finding and the material relevant thereto, and can find no reason not to accept it. There is, therefore, no substance in this second contention.
In the result both the appeals are allowed. The appellant in the circumstances will get only the companyts incurred before the High Court on remand in Civil Appeal No.

edges.explanation: Holding that ordinance applies to wakf property and mutwalli's interest addresses the central issue

anchor.surface_text: the contention is based on the definition of the phrase evacuee property in the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949, which is as follows Evacuee property means any property in which an evacuee has any right or interest or which is held by him under any deed of trust or other instrument. ... The words used in this definition are of sufficient amplitude and we are of the opinion that the Bihar definition comprised also wakf property and interest therein.
In the result both the appeals are allowed. The appellant in the circumstances will get only the companyts incurred before the High Court on remand in Civil Appeal No.
